advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with 16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br> To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated 1985 <br><br> "I pianote, it takes note"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''God created the world, DAI put it under CP/M''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> A computer that, for the first time, works with you rather than just for you. Hardware and Software co-ordinating perfectly, Apricot arrives complete and ready to work.<br> The MicroScreen on the keyboard, unique to Apricot, performs a variety of practical functions as a calculator, calendar, time display, and as a window on the screen. Most signifIcantly the MicroScreen prompts and assists the user by presenting simple options whilst running applications.<br> Incorporating the very latest advances in computer technology, Apricot uses 31/2" pocket-size diskettes. Secure and compact, yet offering increased storage capacity.<br> As you'd expect with a 4th generation system, Apricot offers true 16-bit processing, multi-processor architecture and 256k RAM as standard. <br><br> With Pulsar 16-bit business software and compatibility with the best selling ACT Sirius 1 and IBM PC, Apricot already has the largest available software library. <br><br> Apricot includes over £750 of software­ - SuperCalc spreadsheet, business and communications software - to ensure that your system is immediately effective. And because executives are not office bound, Apricot offers portability, a further feature aimed at improving efficiency.<br> Powerful sleek and sophisticated and all at an amazing 4th generation price.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This November 1982 advert introduces the new CoCo 1 price : $299 instead of $399.<br><br> Even if the advert said:<br><font color="#666666">"Hurry - this fantastic offer ends december 31, 1982" </font><br>the price never came back to $399.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE BUSINESS GRAPHICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Apple graphics package was launched in September 1982. It was available for both the Apple II and Apple III.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">As you know, one picture is worth a few thousand numbers.<br> As you may not know, Apple Business Graphics software can generate more types of pictures, in more colours, using more data than any other graphics package... On the monitor of your choice. And on virtually any printer or plotter on the market...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from Australia<p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OHIO BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMORY BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Vector Graphics also sold various cards for any S-100 systems. This one is a 8 Kb. static RAM card solded for $265 in kit version and $350 assembled.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>

computer.description:
Manufactured by Majesco under license by Sega, the Genesis 3 was a budget release of the Genesis hardware. Appearing in the United States in 1998, it was much smaller than previous versions and shipped with the six button controller included.
However, the Genesis 3 lacked the expansion port of the older models making it incompatible with the Sega CD add-ons. It was also incompatible with the 32X.
A number of games were also re-released by Majesco, who later re-released the Game Gear as well.
_________
Matt adds: The Genesis 3 was compatible with most titles, only a small number of titles wouldn't work. The unit would also freeze if bumped.

emulator.description: Kega is a Sega SG1000, SC3000, Master System, Game Gear, Genesis/Megadrive and SegaCD/MegaCD emulator for Win9x/ME/2000/XP
emulator.name: KEGA

item.description: the action chair||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE ACTION CHAIR</strong></font><br><blockquote>The action chair is a rare item. Connected to a Genesis/Megadrive, it acts as a controller! When you lean backward/forward it tells the Genesis to go down/up and when you lean left/right it tells to go left/right. Two handles on each side offer two buttons each, resulting in 4 buttons : START, SELECT, A & B. <br><br> The Action Chair is basically a chair mounted on a controller. It is thus possible to play all games with it, though it is more convenient to play games like After Burner II, Space Harrier II, Super Thunder Blade, Hang on, Road Rash, Super Monaco GP, etc.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

Documentation|||Page 1|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><strong>> Page 1</strong><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

Documentation|||Page 2|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><strong>> Page 2</strong><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Spycal</b> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.name: Genesis 3
computer.ports: Cartridge, AV out, power adapter, 2 controller ports
computer.ram: 64 KB main, 8 KB secondary, 8 KB sound
computer.sound: Texas Instruments SN76489 4 channel PSG + Yamaha YM2612 6 channel FM
